fr:title.text: First steps in synthetic domain theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: First steps in synthetic domain theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @inproceedings{hyland-1991, author = {Hyland, J. M. E.}, editor = {Carboni, Aurelio and Pedicchio, Maria Cristina and Rosolini, Guiseppe}, address = {Berlin, Heidelberg}, publisher = {Springer Berlin Heidelberg}, booktitle = {Category Theory}, year = {1991}, isbn = {978-3-540-46435-8}, pages = {131--156}, title = {First steps in synthetic domain theory}, }

fr:title.text: Cost-sensitive computational adequacy of higher-order recursion in synthetic domain theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cost-sensitive computational adequacy of higher-order recursion in synthetic domain theory

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:link.title: MFPS ’24: 40th International Conference on Mathematical Foundations of Programming Semantics

fr:meta.fr:link: MFPS ’24: 40th International Conference on Mathematical Foundations of Programming Semantics

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We study a cost-aware programming language for higher-order recursion dubbed PCFcost in the setting of synthetic domain theory (SDT). Our main contribution relates the denotational cost semantics of PCFcost to its computational cost semantics, a new kind of dynamic semantics for program execution that serves as a mathematically natural alternative to operational semantics in SDT. In particular we prove an internal, cost-sensitive version of Plotkin’s computational adequacy theorem, giving a precise correspondence between the denotational and computational semantics for complete programs at base type. The constructions and proofs of this paper take place in the internal dependent type theory of an SDT topos extended by a phase distinction in the sense of Sterling and Harper. By controlling the interpretation of cost structure via the phase distinction in the denotational semantics, we show that PCFcost programs also evince a noninterference property of cost and behavior. We verify the axioms of the type theory by means of a model construction based on relative sheaf models of SDT.

fr:title.text: Type theoretic structure on natural models

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Type theoretic structure on natural models

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A natural model consists of (exactly) the judgmental structure of Martin-Löf type theory, without any connectives or basic types or terms. Here we will explore how structure is imposed on a given natural model.

In Martin-Löf type theory, a connective is usually described as being specified by (1) a formation rule, (2) introduction rules, (3) elimination rules, (4) computation rules, and (5) uniqueness rules. This schema is deceptively simple, as there are a number of places where additional complexity arises:

html:ol.html:li: Some types have projection-style eliminators, like those of \Pi and \Sigma types.
Some types have lifting-style eliminators, like that of the booleans.
Some lifting-style eliminators are dependent, like that of the booleans.
Other lifting-style eliminators are non-dependent, like that of a reflective subuniverse that is not \Sigma -closed, such as the subuniverse of predomains in a model of synthetic domain theory.
Some lifting-style eliminators draw their motives of elimination from the ambient natural model, and others place more restrictions (as in the case of a reflective subuniverse).
Some parameters of a formation rule are held fixed during elimination, and others are not.
Some eliminators have judgmental (strict) uniqueness laws, others do not.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: It is our goal to develop a framework that smoothly handles all of these possibilities. As all the possible parameters pertain to elimination and uniqueness laws, it is natural to consider the formation and introduction rules as the basic data of a type theoretic connective, and then the different ways in which a natural model can be closed under such a connective.

In categorical terms, the formation and introduction rules for a connective K can be understood in terms of a single map {I}\xrightarrow {{\pi }}{F} in \operatorname {Pr}{\mathcal {C}}: the base F represents the premises of the formation rule, and the total space I represents the premises of the introduction rule. The projection itself reflects the fact that, in type theoretic terms, an introduction rule for a given connective presupposes that the premises of the formation rule are satisfied.

The formation rule for dependent products fixes a type \Gamma \vdash A together with a family of types \Gamma .A\vdash B indexed in A. The introduction rule further assumes an element \Gamma .A \vdash b : B. The corresponding connective can therefore be described as the projection {{\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}E}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}p}}{{\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}U} where {\operatorname {Pr}{\mathcal {C}}}\xrightarrow {{{\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}}}{\operatorname {Pr}{\mathcal {C}}} is the polynomial endofunctor U_!\circ p_*\circ E^* associated to {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U}. In type theoretic language, {\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}U classifies families of types, and {\mathopen {}\left \langle p\right \rangle \mathclose {}}E classifies families of types equipped with a section.

The formation rule for the boolean type has no premises whatsoever; there are exactly two introduction forms which each have no premises. Therefore, the boolean connective is described by the map {\mathbf {2}}\xrightarrow {{!}}{\mathbf {1}}.

fr:link.title: Natural models of homotopy type theory

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {U}\xrightarrow {{l}}{V} and {A}\xrightarrow {{r}}{B} be two morphisms in a category \mathcal {E} with pullbacks, such that U,V are exponentiable. Working in the codomain bifibration of \mathcal {E}, we consider the vertical factor of the square {p^V}\xrightarrow {{p^f}}{p^U} as depicted below:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { height = 1.5cm, nw = A^V, sw = B^V, west = p^V, ne = A^U, se = B^U, east = p^U, south = B^f, north = A^f, } \qquad \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram,baseline=(sq/sw.base)] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ ne = p^U, se = B^U, sw = A^U, nw = {\mathopen {}\left (f^U\right )\mathclose {}}^*p^U, south = f^U, north = h_{p^f}, nw/style = pullback, west/style = lies over, east/style = lies over, north/node/style = upright desc, width = 2.5cm, height = 1.5cm, } \node [above = of sq/nw] (nw) {$p^V$}; \draw [->] (nw) to node[sloped,above] {$p^f$} (sq/ne); \draw [->,exists] (nw) to node[upright desc] {$v_{p^f}$} (sq/nw); \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A (weak, strong) left lifting structure for {U}\xrightarrow {{l}}{V} against {A}\xrightarrow {{r}}{B} is then defined to be a (section, inverse) to the vertical factor {p^V}\xrightarrow {{v_{p^f}}}{{\mathopen {}\left (f^U\right )\mathclose {}}^*p^U} in {\mathcal {E}}_{/A^U} depicted above — or equivalently a (section, inverse) to the underlying morphism in \mathcal {E} of the vertical factor.

A type theoretic connective is defined to be a pair of maps I\xrightarrow {\pi }F\xrightarrow {\phi }P in which the first factor represents the projection of formation data from introduction data, and the second factor identifies the fixed parameters of the elimination rule.

An formation square for a type theoretic connective I\xrightarrow {\pi }F\xrightarrow {\phi }P in a family {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{B} is defined to be a commuting square {\pi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{p} as depicted schematically below:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare <sq/>{ nw = I, sw = F, ne = E, se = U, east = p, west = \pi , south = \alpha _F, north = \alpha _I, south/style = {exists,->}, north/style = {exists,->}, height = 1.5cm, } \node [below = 1.5cm of sq/sw] (sw) {$P$}; \draw [->] (sq/sw) to node[left] {$\phi $} (sw); \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a morphism in a category \mathcal {E} with pullbacks, and let {\pi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{p} be a formation square for a connective I\xrightarrow {\pi }F\xrightarrow {\phi }P. Working in the codomain bifibration of \mathcal {E}, we consider the vertical factor of the {\pi }\xrightarrow {{v_\alpha }}{\alpha _F^*p} of the square {\pi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{p}:
Write {{\mathcal {E}}_{/F}}\xrightarrow {{\phi _!}}{{\mathcal {E}}_{/P}} for the induced cocartesian lifting (postcomposition) functor.

html:ol.html:li: An absolute eliminator is defined to be an inverse to {\phi _!\pi }\xrightarrow {{\phi _!v_\alpha }}{\phi _!F} in {\mathcal {E}}_{/P}.

A (weak, strong) eliminator is defined to be a (weak, strong) left lifting structure for {\phi _!\pi }\xrightarrow {{\phi _!v_\alpha }}{\phi _!F} against {P^*E}\xrightarrow {{P^*p}}{P^*U} in {\mathcal {E}}_{/P}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can define the structure of recursors in terms of eliminators. To be very clear, we are not demonstrating the (obvious) fact that a recursor can be implemented using a eliminator: we are saying that a recursor for one formation square is precisely the same thing as a eliminator for a different formation square in a different category.

Let {E}\xrightarrow {{p}}{U} be a morphism in a category \mathcal {E} with pullbacks, and let {\pi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{p} be a formation square for a connective I\xrightarrow {\pi }F\xrightarrow {\phi }P. Let {U^*I}\xrightarrow {{v}}{p} be the following vertical factor in {\mathcal {E}}_{/U}:

Let {F}\xrightarrow {{\phi }}{P} be a further morphism. An (absolute, weak, strong) recursor for {\pi }\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{p} with {F}\xrightarrow {{\phi }}{P} fixed is defined to be an (absolute, weak, strong) eliminator for the following formation square in {\mathcal {E}}_{/U}:
We summarise the basic relationship between the different kinds of eliminators.

html:ol.html:li: Absolute eliminators correspond to projection-style elimination rules, whereas (strong, weak) correspond to lifting-style elimination rules (with, without) judgmental uniqueness rules.
Absolute and strong eliminators are unique whenever they exist.

Weak eliminators are not strictly unique, but they form a contractible space in the sense of homotopy as determined by an identity type; when this identity type satisfies equality reflection, then, the weak eliminators become strong.
If a formation square has an absolute eliminator, then it has a strong eliminator. Although the converse holds in many specific examples, it does not hold in general.
An absolute recursor can be upgraded to an absolute eliminator.
In the presence of dependent sums and (strong, weak) identity types, a (strong, weak) recursor can be upgraded to a (strong, weak) eliminator.

fr:title.text: Formalising synthetic domain theory in univalent foundations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formalising synthetic domain theory in univalent foundations

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Homotopy type theory / univalent foundations is an exciting and new foundation of mathematics in which the classical notion of equality is extended to include not only the strict identifications between elemetns of sets but also symmetries on higher dimensional spaces. The simplest example of a higher-dimensional space is the space of all sets — in which “equality” corresponds to bijection. When a mathematical result is formalised in homotopy type theory, it can have unexpectedly strong consequences: the result holds in all (∞,1)-toposes.

Synthetic domain theory is an approach to studying the semantics of computer programs in which a few small axioms are added to intuitionistic logic or intuitionistic type theory, centering on an object that shall play the role of the Sierpiński space, which can be thought of as the space of programs that produce no output (but might diverge). In the past, synthetic domain theory has mainly been studied in the presence of very strong classical and infinitary axioms: in one tradition, Markov’s principle is always assumed, and in another tradition one makes use of infinitary axioms such as the assumption that the initial lifting algebra (a recursively defined gluing of the Sierpiński space onto itself ad infinitum) can be computed as a sequential colimit.

Overemphasis of classical and infinitary assumptions has certainly dampened efforts to develop a unified synthetic domain theory that can serve as base-line truth on which to build further and more refined notions of computational space. Furthermore, many difficult aspects of synthetic domain theory were developed prior to the current understanding of type theory (with its universes, etc.) — and are thus ripe for revisiting and simplification under the aegis of modern dependent type theory. I propose a project to formalise the basics of synthetic domain theory in homotopy type theory, most likely as an extension to Martín Hötzel Escardó’s TypeTopology library.

Finally, an application of synthetic Tait computability to security and information flow control is identified: a security class is a phase distinction between low and high security. The preliminary results presented in this section have been substantially improved upon by Sterling and Harper, adding support for general recursion and termination-insensitive noninterference by combining synthetic Tait computability with synthetic domain theory.

fr:title.text: Weeknotes 2025-W15 › Two papers to appear in LICS ’25 › With Leoni Pugh: When is the partial map classifier a Sierpiński cone?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Weeknotes 2025-W15 › Two papers to appear in LICS ’25 › With Leoni Pugh: When is the partial map classifier a Sierpiński cone?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Leoni Pugh is my old Part III student from 2023–2024, and this work builds on her Part III dissertation. The goal of our paper was to better understand the relationship between two approaches to partial functions in denotational semantics:

html:ol.html:li: “Geometrical” partiality / “the Sierpiński cone”: freely add a lowest element to the space representing a given data type. This is useful for defining functions whose inputs are partially defined, because you can do a case-analysis on the definedness of the input.

“Logical” partiality / “the partial map classifier”: representing partially defined elements of a space X by pairs
( p,x )
where p is a proposition and x is a function from isTrue
( p )
to X. This is useful for defining functions whose outputs are partially defined.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In traditional domain theory as developed by Scott, the two kinds of partiality coincide—even constructively. I am, however, interested in synthetic domain theory which abstracts away from continuity and limits and lets you just use sets and functions rather than cpos and continuous functions—provided that you avoid non-constructive principles like the Axiom of Choice or the Law of Excluded Middle. The starting point of our work is my observation that the two notions cannot coincide absolutely in synthetic domain theory, but that there may be restricted subuniverses in which they do coincide. The main result of our paper is to define such a subuniverse, made possible by my discovery of the based Segal condition—a strengthening of the usual Segal condition for higher categories.

A broader motivation of this work is to develop synthetic domain theory and synthetic higher category theory within the same framework. Whereas synthetic domain theory traditionally concerned itself with spaces that behaved like ω-complete partial orders (but where all functions are automatically monotone and continuous), the same ideas (if applied within homotopy type theory) allow you to consider spaces that behave like ∞-categories with colimits of ω-chains (but where all functions are automatically ∞-functorial and ω-continuous). I believe that unifying domain theory and higher category theory will prove useful for studying things like the denotational semantics of concurrency, which is inherently higher-dimensional.
